data.text:
Charles Bukowski’s writing is compulsively self-destructive and lives in a way that is unsympathetic and bitter.

He talks about suffering, death,bad luck, his addiction to alcohol, his inability to cope with loneliness and boredom.

Bukowski’s writing chooses authenticity over conformity of making life and existence more endurable through art.

When you read bukowski, you can interpret some serious psychological problems like emotional deprivation, childhood trauma, emotional neglect, crippled masculinity, hedonistic escapism.

Bukowski’s life was not perpetually joyful, he embodies the kind of cynicism we don’t say out loud to anyone, perhaps not even to our own selves.

His characters are not Hero archetype, they completely reject conventional heroic traits and instead are deeply flawed and morally ambiguous.

His characters are antisocial, repulsive and misantropic.

Bukowski has a very dark humor which is an obvious escaping mechanism.

The book I’m rereading this week is “Ham on Rye’

reading this book really broke my heart severely.

Here are some Bukowski’s books read by me:

Women

Factotum

Ham on Rye

Notes of dirty old man

Tales of ordinary madness

The flash of lightning from behind the mountain.

Have you ever read any of Bukowski’s writing?
